content: The Corporate Fraud Accountability Act of 2002, also known as the Act, establishes higher maximum penalties for mail and wire fraud. The Corporate Fraud Accountability Act of 2002 increases penalties for mail and wire fraud, as well as securities fraud under Section 1348 of title 18, United States Code. The Corporate Fraud Accountability Act of 2002 increases penalties for securities fraud related to the purchase or sale of registered securities under specific sections of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and the Securities Act of 1933. Offenders may face fines, imprisonment up to 25 years, or both. The Corporate Fraud Accountability Act of 2002 enhances penalties for securities fraud, including tampering with records or obstructing official proceedings under the United States Code. Offenders may be fined or imprisoned for up to 20 years. The United States Sentencing Commission is requested to promptly review and consider new sentencing guidelines for securities and accounting fraud. They should provide enhancements for officers or directors of publicly traded corporations who commit fraud and related offenses. The Commission must also submit an explanation of their actions to Congress and any additional policy recommendations for combating these offenses. The Sentencing Commission is asked to review sentencing guidelines for securities and accounting fraud, ensuring seriousness and consistency. They should consider aggravating or mitigating circumstances for exceptions and adjust offense levels and enhancements accordingly. The Sentencing Commission is tasked with reviewing sentencing guidelines for securities and accounting fraud to ensure adequacy in cases of obstruction of justice and fraud offenses with a significant number of victims. Necessary changes will be made to the guidelines to align with the purposes of sentencing as outlined in the law. The United States Sentencing Commission is requested to promptly issue guidelines or amendments related to sentencing for securities and accounting fraud, obstruction of justice, and fraud offenses with numerous victims, in accordance with section 3553(a)(2) of title 18, United States Code. The Commission must act within 120 days of the enactment of this Act, following the procedures of the Sentencing Reform Act of 1987. SEC. 5. DEBTS NONDISCHARGEABLE IF INCURRED IN VIOLATION OF SECURITIES FRAUD LAWS. Section 523(a) of title 11, United States Code, is amended to include a new paragraph (19) that covers claims related to violations of Federal securities laws, State securities laws, common law fraud, deceit, or manipulation in connection with the purchase or sale of any security. The amendment to Section 523(a) of title 11, United States Code, includes a new paragraph (19) covering claims related to violations of securities laws, fraud, deceit, or manipulation in connection with securities transactions. This encompasses judgments, settlements, or orders for damages, fines, penalties, restitution, disgorgement, attorney fees, costs, or other payments by the debtor. SEC. 6. CORPORATE RESPONSIBILITY FOR FINANCIAL REPORTS. Chapter 63 of title 18, United States Code is amended to include a new section requiring corporate officers to certify financial reports filed with the Securities Exchange Commission. The certification must state that the financial statements accurately represent the issuer's operations and financial condition. Failure to comply with this requirement may result in criminal penalties. The new section in Chapter 63 of title 18, United States Code imposes criminal penalties for knowingly or willfully violating the requirement for corporate officers to certify financial reports filed with the Securities Exchange Commission. Penalties include fines up to $1,000,000 and imprisonment up to 10 years for knowing violations, and fines up to $5,000,000 and imprisonment up to 20 years for willful violations. SEC. 7 introduces penalties for attempts and conspiracies to commit offenses against the United States, with the same penalties as the intended offense. SEC. 8 increases criminal penalties under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934. SEC. 8 amends the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 to increase criminal penalties, with fines raised to $5,000,000 and imprisonment up to 20 years. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is amended to allow the Commission to issue a temporary freeze order when investigating possible violations involving publicly traded securities. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 amendment allows the Commission to petition a Federal district court for a temporary order requiring an issuer to escrow payments in an interest-bearing account for 45 days, with a hearing unless impracticable or contrary to public interest. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 amendment allows the Commission to petition a Federal district court for a temporary order requiring an issuer to escrow payments in an interest-bearing account for 45 days, with a hearing unless impracticable or contrary to public interest. The temporary order becomes effective immediately, is served upon the parties subject to it, and remains enforceable for 45 days unless set aside, limited, or suspended by a court. Extensions for up to an additional 45 days may be granted by the court for good cause shown. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 allows the Commission to petition a Federal district court for a temporary order requiring an issuer to escrow payments for up to 45 days, extendable for another 45 days with court approval if good cause is shown. If violations are charged before the order expires, it remains in effect until legal proceedings conclude. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 allows the Commission to petition a Federal district court for a temporary order requiring an issuer to escrow payments for up to 45 days. If violations are not charged before the order expires, the escrow terminates at the end of the effective period. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 allows the Commission to petition a Federal district court for a temporary order requiring an issuer to escrow payments for up to 45 days. If violations are not charged before the order expires, the disputed payments (with accrued interest) shall be returned to the issuer or other affected person. Additionally, a technical amendment is made to Section 21C(c)(2) of the Act. SEC. 10. AUTHORITY OF THE COMMISSION TO PROHIBIT PERSONS FROM SERVING AS OFFICERS OR DIRECTORS. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and the Securities Act of 1933 are amended to give the Commission the authority to prohibit individuals who have violated certain regulations from serving as officers or directors of registered issuers. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and the Securities Act of 1933 are amended to allow the Commission to ban individuals who have violated regulations from being officers or directors of registered issuers. SEC. 11. RETALIATION AGAINST INFORMANT. Amends Section 1513 of title 18, United States Code to penalize retaliation against informants providing truthful information on Federal offenses to law enforcement. Penalties include fines or imprisonment up to 10 years.
